sen.j: 初代大森漸斎は京都の人で、若い頃は剣術を好んでしたが、後に小堀遠州の門に入る。
sen.e: Zansai OMORI, the first-generation head of the Tamagawa Enshu school, whose home town was Kyoto, preferably practiced kenjutsu (the art of swordsmanship) when young; he subsequently entered the Kobori Enshu school.

sen.j: 「玉川」は霊元天皇に竹二重切花入を献上した際に賜った号である。
sen.e: The presentation of a 'take niju giri hana ire (bamboo vase)' to Emperor Reigen brought him go (a pseudonym), 'Tamagawa.'
His go (a pseudonym) 'Tamagawa' was received by Emperor Reigen on the presentation of 'take niju giri hana ire' (bamboo vase).

sen.j: 2代杖信は閑院宮の茶頭を務め、以降公家との関わりが強かったが、3代有斐の亡きあと嗣子の礼座が早世したため断絶する。
sen.e: With Joshin, the second tea master, serving as a sado (a person in charge of the tea ceremony) for Kainnomiya (one of the Imperial families), the relationship with court nobles had deepened since then, but after the death of the third head, Yuri, the premature death of the following heir Reiza caused the extinction of the Omori family line.

sen.j: およそ30年の空白期間を経て、3代有斐より皆伝を受けた閑院宮美仁親王の意により橘正之が大森家を復興し4代宗震となった。
sen.e: After the absence of the head of the school for thirty years, Masayuki TACHIBANA revived the Omori family to become the fourth-generation head, Soshin, under instructions of Imperial Prince Kainnomiya Haruhito, who had been certified as full proficiency from the third head, Yuri.

sen.j: 橘正之は花山院家の家司で従五位下に叙せられていたが、美仁親王の家臣である南部主悦を通して伝を受けた。
sen.e: Ordained as Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), Masayuki TACHIBANA, who was a keishi (household superintendent) of the Kazanin family, was instructed by Shuetsu NANBU, a vassal of Prince Haruhito.

sen.j: もともと2代杖信の弟子で西勝寺の皆乗院公道が秋田に茶道を普及していた縁があり、宗震は4回にわたって秋田を訪れ伝道に携わり、それ以来秋田を中心に東北地方に広まっている。
sen.e: The earliest connection with Kodo Kaijoin of Saisho-ji Temple, who was a disciple of the second-generation head, Joshin, and who spread tea ceremony in Akita, led Soshin to visit it four times and to assist in promoting the school of tea ceremony; therefore, the Tamagawa Enshu school has spread over the Tohoku region, especially in Akita since then.

sen.j: 5代宗龍のとき明治維新を迎え、東京に移って有栖川宮の茶頭を務めた。
sen.e: The Meiji Restoration saw Soryu, the fifth-generation head, move to Tokyo and serve as a sado for Arisugawa no Miya.

sen.j: 宗龍は明治19年（1886年）に玉川遠州流と称し、伝来の法をもとにして玉川遠州流煎茶法を完成させた。
sen.e: In 1886, Soryu called his way of tea ceremony as Tamagawa Enshu school and completed the Tamagawa Enshu school of sencha-ho (green tea method) based on the method handed from their ancestors.

sen.j: 6代岑尾は5代宗龍の娘で、京都で高等女学校の英語教師をしていたが、晩年になって茶道の伝道に努めた。
sen.e: Mineo, the sixth head of the school, was a daughter of the fifth head, Soryu, and an English teacher of a girls 'high school in Kyoto; however, she promoted the Tamagawa Enshu school of tea ceremony in her late years.

sen.j: 6代岑尾のあとは、弟子の中野賢子（大森柳庵）の夫が家元を継ぎ7代宗夢となった。
sen.e: Succeeding to the iemoto (the head family of a school) after Mineo, the husband of Masako NAKANO, one of Mineo's disciples, become the seventh head, Somu.
